intro: Rosa glauca var. vallisfagorum, commonly known as the alpine rose, is a variant of the glaucous rose that thrives in high-altitude environments. It is characterized by its compact growth habit and hairy stems, which help it withstand cold and arid conditions. The plant produces small, pale pink to white flowers with five petals, often appearing in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are typically narrow and covered in fine hairs, adapting to the harsh conditions of its native habitat. Rosa glauca var. vallisfagorum is native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia and is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological resilience.
